labMTsimple package¶

Submodules¶

labMTsimple.speedy module¶

class labMTsimple.speedy.sentiDict(corpus, datastructure='dict', bootstrap=False, stopVal=0.0, bananas=False, loadFromFile=False)[source]¶

An abstract class to score them all.

bootstrapify()[source]¶

Extend the lists without stems to include stems.

folders = ('labMT', 'ANEW', 'LIWC', 'MPQA-lexicon', 'liu-lexicon', 'Warriner')¶
loadDict(bananas)[source]¶

Load the corpus into a dictionary, straight from the origin corpus file.

makeDaTrie()[source]¶

Turn a dictionary into a da_trie.

makeListsFromDict(userdict)[source]¶

Make lists from a dict, used internally.

makeMarisaTrie()[source]¶

Turn a dictionary into a marisa_trie.

matcherTrieBool(word)[source]¶

MatcherTrieBool(word) just checks if a word is in the list.

Works for both trie types.

Only one needed to make the plots.

Only use this for coverage, so don’t even worry about using with a dict.

matcherTrieDa(word, wordVec, count)[source]¶

Not sure what this one does.

matcherTrieDict(word, wordVec, count)[source]¶

Not sure what this one does.

matcherTrieMarisa(word, wordVec, count)[source]¶

Not sure what this one does.

openWithPath(filename, mode)[source]¶

Helper function for searching for files.

scoreTrieDa(wordDict)[source]¶

Score a wordDict using the da_trie backend.

INPUTS:

-wordDict is a favorite hash table of word and count.

scoreTrieDict(wordDict)[source]¶

Score a wordDict using the dict backend.

INPUTS:

-wordDict is a favorite hash table of word and count.

scoreTrieMarisa(wordDict)[source]¶

Score a wordDict using the marisa_trie backend.

INPUTS:

-wordDict is a favorite hash table of word and count.

titles = ['LabMT', 'ANEW', 'LIWC', 'MPQA', 'Liu', 'Warriner']¶
wordVecifyTrieDa(wordDict)[source]¶

Make a word vec from word dict using da_trie backend.

INPUTS:

-wordDict is our favorite hash table of word and count.

wordVecifyTrieDict(wordDict)[source]¶

Make a word vec from word dict using dict backend.

INPUTS:

-wordDict is our favorite hash table of word and count.

wordVecifyTrieMarisa(wordDict)[source]¶

Make a word vec from word dict using marisa_trie backend.

INPUTS:

-wordDict is our favorite hash table of word and count.

labMTsimple.speedy.u(x)[source]¶

Python 2/3 agnostic unicode function

labMTsimple.storyLab module¶

labMTsimple.storyLab.allEmotions(tmpStr, *allDicts)[source]¶

Compute scores from a list of dicts and return a list of scores.

labMTsimple.storyLab.emotion(tmpStr, someDict, scoreIndex=1, shift=False, happsList=[])[source]¶

Take a string and the happiness dictionary, and rate the string.

If shift=True, will return a vector (also then needs the happsList).

labMTsimple.storyLab.emotionFileReader(stopval=1.0, lang='english', min=1.0, max=9.0, returnVector=False)[source]¶

Load the dictionary of sentiment words.

Stopval is our lens, $Delta _h$, read the labMT dataset into a dict with this lens (must be tab-deliminated).

With returnVector = True, returns tmpDict,tmpList,wordList. Otherwise, just the dictionary.

labMTsimple.storyLab.emotionFileReaderRaw(stopval=1.0, fileName=u'labMT1raw.txt', min=1.0, max=9.0, returnVector=False)[source]¶

Idea here was originally to use the individual word scores to sample from for each word, and generate a more statistically sound standard deviation. Never finished because the raw file that I was playing with was incomplete.

labMTsimple.storyLab.emotionV(frequencyVec, scoreVec)[source]¶

Given the frequency vector and the score vector, compute the happs.

Doesn’t use numpy, but equivalent to np.dot(freq,happs)/np.sum(freq).

labMTsimple.storyLab.generatePDF(filename, program='rsvg')[source]¶

Use rsvg or inkscape to make a PDF from the SVG.

labMTsimple.storyLab.generateSVG(htmlfile, output='')[source]¶

Use phantomjs and the local crowbar to make the svg file.

labMTsimple.storyLab.shift(refFreq, compFreq, lens, words, sort=True)[source]¶

Compute a shift, and return the results.

If sort=True, will return the three sorted lists, and sumTypes. Else, just the two shift lists, and sumTypes (words don’t need to be sorted).

labMTsimple.storyLab.shiftHtml(scoreList, wordList, refFreq, compFreq, outFile)[source]¶

Make an interactive shift for exploring and sharing.

The most insane-o piece of code here (lots of file copying, writing vectors into html files, etc).

Accepts a score list, a word list, two frequency files and the name of an HTML file to generate

** will make the HTML file, and a directory called static that hosts a bunch of .js, .css that is useful.

labMTsimple.storyLab.shiftPDF(scoreList, wordList, refFreq, compFreq, outFile)[source]¶

Generate a PDF wordshift directly from frequency files!

outfile should probably end in .html, and this will make a file that ends in .svg,.eps,and .pdf in addition to html file, in making the wordshift.

labMTsimple.storyLab.stopper(tmpVec, labMTvector, labMTwords, stopVal=1.0, ignore=[])[source]¶

Take a frequency vector, and 0 out the stop words.

Will always remove the nig* words.

Return the 0’ed vector.
